Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ocean Tracks: Investigating Marine Migrations in a Changing Ocean

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ocean Tracks: Investigating Marine Migrations in a Changing Ocean, a collaboration between Education Development Center, Inc. (EDC), and Stanford University's Hopkins Marine Station, is developing a unique model of how to enable high school students to use authentic scientific data via an interactive Web-interface. Ocean Tracks is developing and classroom testing powerful Web-based visualization and analysis tools derived from state-of-the-art knowledge about how to support student inquiry with data. An interactive website provides access to near-real-time and archival data from electronically tagged marine animals, drifting buoys, and Earth-orbiting satellites collected through the Global Tagging of Pelagic Predators, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Adopt-a-Drifter, and MY NASA DATA programs. Powerful Web-based visualization and analysis tools, derived from state-of-the-art knowledge about how to support student inquiry with data, allow students to learn and apply core concepts in ecology, biology, environmental science, earth science, oceanography, and climate science.

Concurrently, agencies such as the NSF, NOAA, and NASA are making significant investments in sophisticated cyberinfrastructures (CI) that will make available a treasure trove of scientific data via the Internet to scientists and educators; there is tremendous potential for this data to transform teaching and learning by engaging students in authentic scientific work. However, modifying expert-data interfaces for use by students and supporting students as they engage in scientific inquiry with data are significant challenges. There is an urgent need for model programs such as Ocean Tracks that instantiate the best knowledge of experienced educators and education researchers, practicing scientists, and technology experts. Ocean Tracks harnesses the promise of emerging CI to engage high school students in the use of data visualization tools to study the movement patterns and habitat usage of marine animals (e.g., sharks, tunas, turtles, seals, and seabirds) in relation to oceanographic variables (e.g., sea surface temperature, chlorophyll, and current speed and direction). The knowledge gained from Ocean Tracks will have broad impact by serving as a model for designing and implementing projects in which students, teachers, and scientists collaborate to conduct scientific research, even in classrooms that are far from the ocean and scientists' laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean Tracks: Investigating Marine Migrations in a Changing Ocean (Ocean Tracks) was a three-year research and development project that led to the creation of a student-friendly scientific data Web interface – one that allows high school students to visualize and investigate the migration tracks of great white sharks, elephant seals, Bluefin tuna, and Laysan albatross in the North Pacific Ocean. Resulting from a collaboration between Education Development Center, Inc. (EDC), and Stanford University’s Hopkins Marine Station, the Ocean Tracks interface makes accessible to students professionally collected data from the Tagging of Pacific Predators (TOPP) Program, NOAA’s Drifter Program, the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis at UC Santa Barbara, and Earth-orbiting satellites. Students can use the Ocean Tracks interface to explore and make connections between animal movement patterns and ocean characteristics such as sea surface temperature, chlorophyll levels, and currents (Figures 1-4). With interactive map-based animal tracks, graphs, overlays, and other tools, the interface allows students to explore questions of current importance to marine scientists, such as: What might influence the movement of large marine species? Where do marine species congregate, and how might we target these areas for protection? The interface can be accessed through a website that includes tutorial videos, a resource library, sample curriculum modules, video interviews with TOPP scientists, and project background information (http://oceantracks.org/).

Ocean Tracks was inspired by the treasure trove of scientific data that agencies such as NSF, NOAA, and NASA have made available through the Internet to scientists and educators. There is tremendous potential for these “big data” to transform teaching and learning by providing opportunities for students to participate in the authentic practices of science and to develop data skills that are becoming increasingly important in a variety of professions. But because Web interfaces to these data have typically been designed for expert rather than novice users, there has been a need to design user-friendly interfaces that can engage and excite high school students in the practices of science with complex, professionally collected data. The Ocean Tracks project has created a novel data interface and accompanying resources to serve as a model for how science educators may meet this need.

Envisioned as Phase 1 of a multi-phase effort, the Ocean Tracks project focused on developing the Web interface through iterative cycles of individual user testing and pilot tests in high school classrooms. The project also gathered information about the types and design of additional supports that are needed to help students build skills in using professionally collected scientific data to learn about the natural world. Lessons learned from the design of the Ocean Tracks interface are summarized in Ocean Tracks: A Case Study (2015). Major findings are:

  • In classroom tests, high school students found the major functions and tools of the Ocean Tracks interface generally easy to use and understand.

  • Students demonstrated a wide array of scientific data practices in Ocean Tracks work samples, including the generation of scientific claims supported by quantitative evidence and reasoning.
